meanings.definition: To give up; to leave behind.
examples: Last year Jack broke his arm and had to abandon his hopes of playing on the baseball team.
Some people think buying expensive designer clothes is frivolous and a waste of money.

images.alt: Photo of a large room with fancy furniture and decoration.
images.description: A room with overly fancy furniture, paintings, and gold decorations.
images.caption: This room's decorations and furniture are frivolous; they are more fancy and elaborate than most people want or need.

source.title: Musical Organ in Front of Large Painting
source.author: Jensen V

examples: Many parents think that contemporary songs lack good lyrics.
Newscasters fear that people will not watch their programs if the stories are not dramatic enough.

images.alt: Surprised young woman browsing mobile phone
images.description: A person looking at her phone screen. She has a surprised expression on her face.
images.caption: Dramatic stories catch people's attention.

source.title: Surprised young woman browsing mobile phone
source.author: Andrea Piacquadio

examples: Karla exploited her sister’s weakness for chocolate when she offered her a candy bar in exchange for help with a school project.
They say that today’s reporters often present only one of many views on complex issues such as immigration or the conflict in the Middle East.

images.alt: Photo of two children pulling a toy in opposite directions.
images.description: Two children, each holding an arm of a stuffed toy bear. Each child pulls the toy in the direction opposite of the other child.
images.caption: Just one toy to share among two people can be a source of conflict.

source.title: Arguing brothers pulling soft toy to sides
source.author: Victoria Borodinova

meanings.definition: To cause a change in; influence.
examples: Some programs report on celebrity life, on everyday topics like shopping, or on strange events that do not affect many people.

meanings.definition: Having a complicated structure; not simple.
examples: They say that today’s reporters often present only one of many views on complex issues such as immigration or the conflict in the Middle East.

images.alt: Photo of math equations written on a black board.
images.description: A person holds a piece of writing chalk in front of a chalkboard. The chalkboard has many mathematical equations written on it, suggesting that the person is trying to solve a complex math problem.
images.caption: Mathematics can help solve complex science problems.

source.title: Person Holding a Chalk in Front of the Chalk Board
source.author: JESHOOTS.com

meanings.definition: The start or cause of something.
examples: Some news sources say that they are giving the public what it wants.

images.alt: Photo of a phone and a newspaper on a table.
images.description: A phone and a newspaper on a table.
images.caption: A newspaper and a smartphone are both sources of news and information.

examples: Is America more interested in being entertained than in learning about what’s happening in the world?

images.alt: Photo of women reading a magazine
images.description: Photo of three women looking at a magazine. They are smiling.
images.caption: Are news sources meant to entertain, inform, or both?

examples: They say that today’s reporters often present only one of many views on intricate issues such as immigration or the discord in the Middle East.
